newsitem.title: USA: ADR REPORT - Nokia up, boosted by rumors.
newsitem.headline: ADR REPORT - Nokia up, boosted by rumors.

text.p: Finnish telephone equipment company Nokia Group rose in record territory amid quiet trade in American Depositary Receipts (ADRs).
Nokia, which closed at a 12-month record of 68-1/2 Thursday, was up another 7/8 to 69-3/8 in late morning. Traders said it was boosted by market rumors that the company was buying back its stock.
Nokia denied the rumors. Volume was 862,500 ADRs, putting Nokia among the most-active ADRs.
Fellow Nordic telephone equipment company Telefon AB L.M. Ericsson also was up, rising 1/4 to 36-7/8.

Russian telecommunications company Vimpel-Communications fell one to 30-5/8 amid a secondary offering of about 3.5 million shares. Vimpel was on the New York Stock Exchange's most-active list, with 1.2 million ADRs traded.
Among other European ADRs, Britain's BOC Group Plc was up 1/2 to 33. The company has been a rumored buyer of Healthdyne Technologies Inc, a medical device company.
BOC volume was 850,000 ADRs, made up of a single block trade. The volume was far above normal daily activity of 5,840 ADRs and details about the block trade were not immediately available.
Brazilian bank Unibanco Group was up 7/8 to 35-1/4 on volume of 1.1 million ADRs, a day after debuting on the New York Stock Exchange. It was among the most-active shares on the exchange.
Advancers led decliners 259 to 181 among 814 ADRs, and traders said activity was quiet because of the upcoming three-day holiday weekend.
The ADR group was up 0.31 percent and volume was 31 million ADRs. ADRs allow U.S. trading of foreign shares.
